This leaves him with only 3/5 parts still uneaten from the whole pie which totals up to 2,821,391 * (3 / 5) = 1,692,834.6 or approximately 1,692,835 since we cannot really consume .6 portion of any food item here. By consuming these portions over two days, this means now he would eat another set amount equaling about halfway through what remained after eating earlier; i.e., roughly around ((1,692,835)/2). During this period while waiting eagerly patiently until midnight when all dining establishments close their operations temporarily due tomorrow morning rush hour traffic jams... Thus reducing available time even further than expected as most people tend toward fast consumption once hunger strikes again leading them towards excess caloric intake resulting into severe stomach aches later during sleep

direct_answer.text:
Let’s solve this problem systematically using fractions instead of percentages wherever possible.:
Initial Number Of Pieces = 2813911
Pieces Eaten First Day= InitialNumberOfPieces*((2/5))  
RemainingAfterFirstDay=(InitialNumberOfPieces*(3/5))

0.user_question: Tobias bought a big pizza with 2821391 pieces. He ate 2/5 of the pieces on the first day, 10 pieces on the second day, and 7/13 of the remaining pieces on the third day. How many pizza pieces has he eaten so far?

direct_answer.text:
First calculate Tobias’ consumption during the three days separately before summing up everything together . Let us assume that one slice contains ‘x’ calories (we don’t need it here). We can write down equations according to this scenario as follows :  
Day_One_Pieces=Total Pieces*CoefficientForEateronThisDayInPercentageForm   
So Day One Consumption would equal ((2/5)*(total)) Calories i.e.,((2/5)*2821391)Calories    
Similarly ,Second_Day_Consumption=(NumberOfPiecesOnThatSpecificDay)= Total Number Of Slices-(Calorie% consumed)-Remaining slices     
and Third_Day_consumption=(remaining Pizzas*(coefficient for person)/who consumes them ) which equals Total Remaining %ofpizza multiplied by coefficientforperson who consumesit+ Second Day Eaterspiecescalorietotal -(Dayonepercentateachereats)(Dayonepiececount×X)+ThirdDayPercentAgeattherestingnumberofpeices× X       Here we find out what percentage was actually left when calculating
